Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the deficit reduction in the second 10 years by stating that it will be $1.2 trillion, while the CBO analysis only projects a reduction in deficits "in a broad range around one-half percent of GDP."
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support for the $1.2 trillion deficit reduction in the second 10 years, as it is based on extrapolation and projections of future GDP growth.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that GDP will continue to rise at an average of 4 percent a year for each of the next 10 years, which may be a problematic assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim presents an alternative explanation to the $1.2 trillion deficit reduction, suggesting that Pelosi's estimate may actually be conservative, according to the director of federal fiscal policy at the left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities.
